entry.title: Re: Report using the "Main Contact" field in account header
entry.content:
Dear Cl√≥vis,
 
You may try to create a join data source.
Steps:
1. Go to Business analytics work center.
2. Go to Design data source.
3. New.
4. Join data source.
5. Choose the data sources.
6. Choose the join conditions.
7. Save > run
 
just remind the join condition fields must be unique, which means they cannot repeat. Also the join condition must be in the same data format and same number of characters.
 
We will help you to find fields in the complete C4C data source documentation.
 
1. Please, enter in the link below:
 
Complete C4C Data Sources Documentation | SAP Blogs 
[ https://blogs.sap.com/2019/10/30/complete-c4c-data-sources-documentation/#:~:text=Complete%20C4C%20Data%20Sources%20Documentation%20%20%20Data,Account%2C%20Accoun%20...%20%2018%20more%20rows%20 ]
 
2. Type ctrl + F, type the field / data source you are searching for.
 

 Sincerely,
Gustavo
SAP Product Support

entry.title: Large Cap Biopharma: 2024 Valuation Sensitivities
entry.content:
Pfizer: Valuation as a Reflection of Complexity

Pfizer is often discussed in the market through simplified narratives: post-pandemic normalization, patent expirations, or near-term earnings pressure. While each element matters, none is sufficient by itself to explain Pfizer‚Äôs performance, strategic positioning, or valuation.

Earlier this year, we developed a detailed analysis of Pfizer, including a Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) valuation model, to better understand the company‚Äôs potential for long-term value creation. A few months later, it is useful to step back and reflect on that analysis ‚Äî not to revise conclusions, but to place them in a broader business context.

This note follows a bottom-up structure: starting with business and portfolio dynamics, moving through capital allocation and profitability, and only then connecting these elements to valuation and market pricing. While COVID-related effects remain part of the recent financial history, they are not the central driver of the long-term dynamics discussed here.

Pfizer operates one of the most complex business models in global healthcare. Its activities span research-intensive innovation, large-scale manufacturing, regulatory navigation, portfolio lifecycle management, and capital allocation across long time horizons. Even a simple snapshot of Pfizer in Q1 2025 illustrates how many moving parts must work together to sustain performance.

A Business Defined by Scale, Scope, and Long Cycles

Pfizer‚Äôs scale is both an advantage and a constraint. A broad portfolio across therapeutic areas and geographies provides diversification, global reach, and operational leverage. At the same time, scale introduces complexity:

  • long development timelines
  • staggered patent cliffs
  • heterogeneous market dynamics
  • continuous reinvestment requirements

Importantly, Pfizer is not a single-product or single-cycle company. Its economic profile reflects the aggregation of many medical solutions at different stages of maturity, each with distinct risk, return, and timing characteristics. As a result, short-term performance is an imperfect proxy for long-term value creation, particularly given long drug investment cycles.

Revenue Is Not a Single Trajectory

One recurring theme from the analysis is that Pfizer‚Äôs revenue profile cannot be understood as a linear trend. Revenue is shaped by several overlapping forces:

  • portfolio turnover as products mature and face loss of exclusivity
  • the timing and slope of pipeline launches
  • geographic mix and pricing dynamics
  • external shocks, normalization effects, and inorganic investments

Rather than viewing revenue volatility as a sign of instability, it is more accurate to see it as a structural feature of large-cap biopharma. The portfolio requires constant rebalancing as some drugs experience revenue decline and others take their place. The central question is not whether revenues fluctuate, but whether the organization can consistently replenish its portfolio.

When we zoom in on pre-LOE drugs, some high-revenue products already show signs of slowing or decline, while others continue to grow but approach patent expiration. This naturally raises the question: what happens to biopharma revenues before, during, and after LOE?

The answer depends on a nuanced interplay of internal actions and external factors ‚Äî including lifecycle management strategies, competitive dynamics, and therapeutic alternatives. These factors can mean the difference between a steep revenue drop and a more controlled decline.

 

In practice, a large biopharma company such as Pfizer constantly experiences both growth and decline across its product portfolio.

While some drugs mature and slow down, others pick up and help sustain revenue continuity. In this sense, large biopharma resembles portfolio management: individual assets rise and fall, requiring ongoing reinvestment and reallocation rather than optimization of any single product.

Inorganic Portfolio Balancing

The need for continuous portfolio renewal naturally leads to a strategic choice: invest internally through R&D, or acquire external assets.

 

A review of Pfizer‚Äôs mergers, acquisitions, and divestitures shows a willingness to act decisively to maintain portfolio relevance. While the pricing of some acquisitions has been debated, the broader pattern is clear: inorganic actions play a central role in shaping portfolio maturity and future growth potential.

 

Capital Allocation Is Central to the Story

Decisions around internal R&D, acquisitions, divestitures, debt management, and shareholder returns collectively shape Pfizer‚Äôs risk profile and future earnings power.

Capital allocation at this scale is not about optimizing a single metric in a single year. It centers on balancing:

  • flexibility
  • resilience
  • long-term value creation

Over the last seven years, Pfizer has invested more than $70 billion through inorganic transactions ‚Äî a magnitude comparable to its organic R&D spending. Beyond acquisition prices and divestiture proceeds, these transactions also carry ongoing costs, including post-merger integration and transition services (TSA).

Criticism around capital deployment often focuses on the argument that value erosion reflects overpayment for acquisitions. In support of this argument, current valuation multiples are often cited as the benchmarks for a fair acquisition consideration.

 

While this perspective deserves consideration, it is incomplete without examining Pfizer‚Äôs broader capital structure and working capital dynamics.

 

To fund both organic and inorganic investments ‚Äî while maintaining dividend payments exceeding $9.5 billion in 2024 ‚Äî Pfizer increased leverage. Total debt rose from approximately $35 billion at the beginning of 2023 to $71 billion a year later, before declining to $64 billion at the start of 2025. With equity of roughly $88 billion, the resulting debt-to-equity ratio stood near 72%.

 

Margins Reflect Strategic Choices, Not Just Efficiency

Operating margins can be scrutinized in isolation, but they reflect deliberate trade-offs. Investment in R&D, business development, manufacturing capabilities, tax optimization and commercial infrastructure all weigh on near-term margins while supporting long-term optionality.

 

Periods of margin compression often coincide with pipeline build-out or integration of acquired assets. Margin recovery, in turn, depends on successful execution and maturation of those investments.

Recognizing margin pressure, Pfizer launched a transformation program aimed at cost reduction. Reviewing this program alongside historical performance allows us to outline plausible ranges for future operating efficiency and margin expansion ‚Äî not as guarantees, but as scenarios grounded in past behavior and structural constraints.

Key Model Assumptions

With revenue dynamics, profitability, and capital deployment established, we then turn to the DCF model.

Fully aware of LOE-related revenue risks, we conservatively project revenue growth of 1% per year over the next five years.

This leads to the following free cash flow components used in the valuation.

As a result, the full Free Cash Flow picture can be summarized as follows:

 

Estimating the Weighted Average Cost of Capital involves both financial analysis and judgment. Once WACC is established, we proceed to the full DCF framework, using both perpetuity growth and terminal EBITDA multiple approaches.

With the WACC estimated, we can proceed to the full DCF model which can be conceptually described as follows:

We utilize both Perpetuity Growth and Terminal Value EBITDA Multiple approaches to estimate Pfizer‚Äôs Enterprise Value on the basis of the above projected financials.

Valuation as an Output, Not an Assumption

While the resulting enterprise value and implied share price are informative, the sensitivity analysis is more revealing.

Given Pfizer‚Äôs transformation efforts following COVID-related normalization, the key question is not whether profitability can improve, but within what range such improvement might plausibly occur ‚Äî and how markets might value that improvement.

We can visualize these plausible scenarios by examining a few parameters that affect enterprise value:

By examining a limited set of parameters that meaningfully affect enterprise value, we can explore scenarios such as:

  • Can Pfizer improve EBIT by 10%?
  • How might such improvement translate into shareholder value?

If operating gains materialize, the model suggests that valuation can respond meaningfully. However, capturing that value requires disciplined execution across all dimensions of the business:

  • portfolio execution with the revenue impact
  • cost discipline for profitability expansion
  • capital allocation including acquisition premium in line with the investor expectations
  • market confidence translating into COE and WACC

Enterprise Value Sensitivity Surface: A Landscape, Not a Point

Not all valuation drivers are within management‚Äôs control. Financial market expectations, interest rates, and macroeconomic conditions add further complexity.

The enterprise value sensitivity surface emphasizes this point by shifting the focus from precision to range. Different combinations of near-term growth and long-term assumptions can justify the same valuation outcome. Pfizer‚Äôs current valuation at almost $190bn EV sits closer to the conservative end of that landscape, reflecting restrained expectations for durability rather than skepticism about the underlying business.

Iso-valuation curves further highlight the trade-offs involved. Slower near-term growth can be offset by stronger long-term persistence, and vice versa. What matters is the combination of assumptions, not any single input.

 

Seen through this lens, Pfizer‚Äôs valuation reflects a market that is cautious about long-term convergence rather than skeptical of near-term economics.

Analyst Positioning Signals Patience, Not Negativity

Consensus analyst ratings reinforce this interpretation. A prevalence of ‚ÄúHold‚Äù recommendations suggests caution rather than bearish conviction. The market appears to be waiting for clearer evidence on execution and durability before adjusting long-term expectations.

 

This positioning aligns with a company viewed as fundamentally sound, yet operating in an environment where confidence is rebuilt gradually.

Market Prices vs. Modeled Value

Comparing Pfizer‚Äôs historical share price with a model-implied value derived in early 2025 helps connect theory with market behavior. The modeled value serves as a stable reference point, while the actual share price fluctuates above and below it.

 

This comparison highlights an important distinction: valuation models estimate economic value, not the path markets take to reach it. Deviations reflect sentiment, timing, and confidence rather than immediate changes in intrinsic worth.

The divergence observed into late 2025 underscores how markets often require tangible proof of recovery and durability before re-rating, even when valuation frameworks remain intact.

The gaps between market price and modeled value are best viewed as expressions of risk perception. Periods below the valuation anchor correspond to elevated uncertainty and higher discount rates, not necessarily to impaired fundamentals.

From this perspective, Pfizer‚Äôs valuation reflects a cautious, evidence-driven market ‚Äî not a rejection of long-term potential.

Bringing the Story Together

Taken together, this bottom-up analysis suggests that Pfizer‚Äôs valuation reflects complexity, long cycles, and conservative market expectations rather than a simple judgment on quality or strategy.

The appearance of undervaluation does not stem from a single mispricing, but from how markets process uncertainty, time, and execution risk. As these uncertainties resolve, valuation is likely to evolve gradually rather than abruptly.

This framework does not argue for an immediate re-rating or a specific price target. Instead, it offers a disciplined way to understand how business fundamentals, strategic decisions, and market psychology interact over time.

In that sense, valuation is not the conclusion of the analysis ‚Äî it is the lens through which Pfizer‚Äôs broader business story is reflected. We plan to revisit this framework once full 2025 financial results become available.

entry.title: move desktop based crystal runtime RPT rendering to cloud???
entry.content:
Background on Our Setup

Historically, our ERP application has been a thick-client desktop app, where the Crystal Reports runtime runs locally on each user's PC. This works well because Crystal can directly access the SQL Server database without issues.

We're now transitioning the ERP to a fully cloud-based, browser-accessible platform. In this new architecture, the browser client can't run the Crystal runtime locally, forcing us to shift report rendering to the server side‚Äîwhich is where the performance bottlenecks are appearing.

We're looking for real-world advice on viable paths forward and want to avoid costly dead ends during this modernization.

Key Questions for the Community

  • Have you successfully moved Crystal Reports to a server-side or cloud-hosted model to support web/browser-based clients? If so, what approach did you use (e.g., SAP Crystal Server on a VM, custom microservices, etc.)?
  • Did you adopt a hybrid approach, keeping some reports in Crystal while migrating others to different tools?
  • What major challenges did you encounter with performance, report scheduling, licensing, or security when moving away from client-side rendering?

We're not expecting a seamless "lift-and-shift" solution‚Äîjust practical insights to guide our decisions as we update the platform.

Thanks for any experiences or recommendations you can share!

entry.title: Re: U.S Tax Reporter Year End 2025
entry.content:
Hello SAP Team, question on the SAP note 3695859 - TAX: Technology and Customer Service Fee tax for Ohio.   What is the intent of this Note and what are being provided as changes/updates via this note? If I understand this new Unemployment Surcharge tax from Ohio, the surcharge is likely getting added to the Employer unemployment experience rate. If so, what is the purpose of this note?

And, if we implement this note (now or as part of the HRSP later), do we need to map this tax type 78 to the tax model? and, if the rates are getting blended into the employer experience rates, wouldn't this be a duplicate? 

I'm trying to figure if we should implement this note now. Even if we don't implement it now, it will eventually come into our system via the HRSP and I want to understand the implications of this.

Thanks
Chandra

entry.title: Mandatory Serial Number Verification in Public Cloud RF
entry.content:
When picking serialized materials, we want to make it PERSON_NAME to verify the number of serial numbers and their values. Currently, RF in public cloud only requires this verification if you are picking a partial quantity and need to specify which serial numbers are being picked. Is there a way to customize this functionality, or is it suggested to build a custom Fiori app for picking? 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Mandatory Serial Number Verification in Public Cloud RF
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

This is a know limitation in the RF system, we don't have a configuration to resolve it like the one to decide only the validation to, for example source bin, batch, and quantity as per the configuration activity (SSCUI) Define Warehouse-Specific Verification Determination. 

However, Adapting UIs for classic applications with Screen Personas allows you to adjust only screen elements that are displayed on a screen when the screen is being used. If some of the elements or screens are not displayed based on context (for example, serial numbers), you can't adjust these elements. Consequently, if you want to influence serial number fields, you must work with a serialized product. To overcome this limitation, you can use design mode on a desktop to adjust RF screens more easily. With design mode, you can see all the RF screens in your current presentation format (portrait or landscape) and all possible fields that belong to the RF transaction, without needing to prepare the necessary data upfront.

Please check the document about the Screen Personas below on topic 5.2 "RF Design Mode" for further information and if could help on your requirement:

ScreenPersonas_RF_EWM_S4H_Cloud

Best regards,

SAP Support.

entry.title: Stock & Quality Management by Handling Unit (Bags / Pallets) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I am currently working on an implementation of SAP S/4HANA Cloud ‚Äì Public Edition, and I have some questions regarding stock management and quality inspection at Handling Unit (HU) level.

1. Stock visibility by Handling Unit (Bags / Pallets)

I am not asking about HU tracking itself (creation, movement, or identification of HUs), but rather about stock visibility and inventory from a business point of view.

My questions are:

  • Is it possible in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to:

    • See how many bags of a specific material are available in stock?

    • See how many pallets of a material exist in stock?

  • Can we perform inventory counting based on Handling Units (for example: inventory by pallet or by bag), instead of only quantity in base unit of measure?

In other words, can we use Handling Units as a stock analysis and inventory dimension, not only as a logistical object?

2. Quality Management by Handling Unit

In addition, I would like to know if Quality Inspection by Handling Unit is supported in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition:

  • Is it possible to perform quality inspection at HU level (for example: inspection per pallet or per bag)?

  • Can inspection lots, results, or usage decisions be managed per Handling Unit, and not only at material / batch level?

From my understanding so far, Quality Management in Public Cloud seems to be mainly material- and batch-based, but I would like to confirm whether there are standard capabilities, configuration options, or known limitations regarding HU-based quality control.

3. Standard vs Limitations

If these scenarios are not supported, I would highly appreciate:

  • Confirmation of the limitation in Public Cloud

  • Any recommended workaround 

  • Clarification if this is supported only in Private Cloud / On-Premise

Thank you in advance for your support and insights.

Best regards,

Credit Limit is $50,000 USD.  New order is for $75,000.  New order takes the customer over the credit limit but the order does not block.  Is there a way to check the order during create, prior to saving, to see if it will cause the customer to exceed the limit?

entry.title: Reacting to missing documents, DYNPRO_FIELD_CONVERSION and other inconsistencies for MM invoices
entry.content:
Hello everyone, I'm glad to share that my Guided Answers page was published today!

It's basically a deeper version of the content from KBA 3116897.

While the KBA already provides the reports that should be followed to address the main inconsistencies in the MM-IV scope, sometimes the steps to run the reports are not clear. Many customers open cases in SAP can actually find the reports, but fail to run them because of some tricky steps that are expected from customer side.

Some reports need specific values in input fields, some others need previous report installation and execution before SAP can carry out with database fixes, some others require manual steps.

For that reason, the Guided Answers page explains the correct approach in detail for each scenario involving inconsistencies.

Those details are now explained in a user-friendly way, to allow customers to react to the inconsistencies promptly and create cases containing everything SAP needs to proceed to database corrections - only if necessary, because some cases can be directly corrected on customer side!

Here's the URL of the Guided Answers page (Consider bookmarking it - maybe you'll need it someday):
https://supportportal-sagaviewer.internal.cfapps.sap.hana.ondemand.com/#/tree/4015/actions/66701

entry.title: Re: RSBCS_REORG not deleting entries in SOST or rows in t...
entry.content:
RSBCS_REORG alone is often not sufficient to reduce entries in SOFFCONT1, especially for documents with status Sent or flagged as non‚Äëdeletable.

To clean up SOFFCONT1 / SOST effectively, SAP recommends executing a sequence of reports, not just one:

  1. RSSO_DELETE_PRIVATE
    ‚Äì Run for document classes RAW and OTF
    ‚Äì Deletes private SAPoffice documents

  2. RSSODFRE
    ‚Äì Frees orphaned SAPoffice documents

  3. RSBCS_REORG
    ‚Äì Again for document classes RAW and OTF

Relevant SAP Notes:

  • 966854 ‚Äì Reorganization ‚Äì New report

  • 1641830 ‚Äì Cleanup of undeletable BCS documents

  • 904711

Important points:

  • Entries with grey diamond status in SOST are usually already sent and may be referenced elsewhere.

  • SOFFCONT1 stores SAPoffice content (mail attachments, spool outputs, workflows, BCS messages).

  • To understand what is filling SOFFCONT1, analyze related tables SOOD / SOOS, which provide creator, creation date, and message type.

  • Table size at DB level will only shrink after a database reorganization, even if rows are deleted.

entry.title: Re: Which Document Area to use for a new repository on th...
entry.content:
For SOFFCONT1 / SAP Office / GOS attachments, the Document Area does not need to be maintained.

The Document Area in OAC0 is mainly relevant for SAP DMS (CV*) scenarios. When the repository is used for SAP Office content (SOFFCONT1, SOFFPHIO, GOS attachments, mails, etc.), SAP does not require a Document Area.

In practice:

  • You can leave the Document Area blank when creating the repository in OAC0

  • Assign the repository via a storage category (OACT)

  • Link document class SOFFPHIO to that storage category (SKPR08)

This setup is fully supported and commonly used when relocating SOFFCONT1 content to SAP Content Server / OpenText.

If you already have a repository with Document Area = Document Management System, it should not be reused for SOFFCONT1. A separate repository without Document Area is the recommended approach.

So yes ‚Äî leaving Document Area empty is correct and supported for SOFFCONT1 use cases.

entry.title: Re: Workflow exploding SOFFCONT1 - what to do?
entry.content:
SOFFCONT1 growth in workflow scenarios is usually caused by workflow mails and attachments created by WF‚ÄëBATCH, which are stored in so‚Äëcalled dark folders.

Deleting mails from inbox/outbox (RSSO_PRIVATE_DELETE / RSSORE00) is not sufficient, because workflow items are not user‚Äëowned.

To reduce SOFFCONT1 size, execute the cleanup reports in the correct sequence:

  1. RSSODLWF ‚Äì deletes workflow‚Äërelated SAP Office documents (WF‚ÄëBATCH)

  2. RSSODFRE ‚Äì frees orphaned SAP Office objects

  3. RSBCS_REORG ‚Äì reorganizes remaining SAP Office data

Run these reports for document classes RAW and OTF, preferably first in test mode.

Also review SAP Notes 536414 and 966854, which explain workflow mail cleanup and SAP Office reorganization.

For long‚Äëterm prevention, consider:

  • Reducing workflow email notifications

  • Routing attachments to an external content server (via OAC0 / OACT)

This approach has proven effective in controlling SOFFCONT1 growth caused by workflow notifications.

entry.title: Re: Does RSBCS_REORG program also deletes SOFFCONT1 data...
entry.content:
No, RSBCS_REORG does NOT delete content from the external archive server.

RSBCS_REORG is used to reorganize and delete SAP Office metadata (for example entries in SOST, SOC3, SOFM, SOOD, etc.) that are no longer needed.
When SOFFCONT1 content has already been migrated to an external content repository (ArchiveLink / Content Server):

  • RSBCS_REORG does not touch the physical documents stored in the archive server

  • It only cleans up SAP Office control and reference records

  • Archived attachments remain safe and accessible via their ArchiveLink references

So in your scenario:

  • You can safely run RSBCS_REORG to reduce entries in SOC3 / SOST / SOFM

  • It will not delete archived SOFFCONT1 content

  • Actual content deletion from the archive is governed by archive retention policies, not RSBCS_REORG

entry.title: Re: long2lob conversion of table SOFFCONT1 ends with ora-03113: end-of-file on communication channel
entry.content: ORA‚Äë03113 during LONG2LOB with DBMS_REDEFINITION is often triggered by underlying ORA‚Äë00600 errors. In such cases, SAP typically recommends opening an Oracle support ticket, as this is a database internal issue and not solvable at application level.

entry.title: Re: how to retrieve data from content repository
entry.content: RSIRPIRL‚Äërelocated SOFFCONT1 documents remain GOS documents. They can still be accessed via OAOR (Business Document Navigator) once the correct object type is known. Technically, retrieval works via: SRGBTBREL (link between business object and SAPoffice object) SO_OBJECT_GET_CONTENT to derive LOIO SOFFPHIO to resolve PHIO ‚Üí physical content in the external repository OAC3 / TOA** tables are not relevant for GOS documents.

entry.title: Re: Reports to determine sent mails per user in SOST
entry.content:
SAP provides a standard report for this requirement.

Use report RSSOSOSTSTAT (transaction SE38).

This report gives statistics on outbound SAP Office emails and allows you to analyze:

  • Number of sent emails

  • User‚Äëwise (sender) distribution

  • Time‚Äëbased selection

  • Status‚Äëbased filtering (sent, error, etc.)

It works directly on SOST data and is suitable even when there are millions of records, avoiding the need to export SOST to Excel manually.

You can view detailed selection options by opening the report documentation in SE38.

entry.title: Re: Personas: How to display each employee's picture?
Re: Lob segment Reorganization failure
entry.content: This is a classic SOFFCONT1 LOB reorganization issue. In Oracle, LOB reorg requires at least 2√ó the LOB size as free space in the tablespace. Additionally, specific Oracle 11.2.0.3 SBP levels have known bugs impacting SOFFCONT1 reorg. Best practices are: Clean up obsolete SAPoffice data first (SAP Note 1634908) Ensure sufficient free space Prefer export/import via BRSPACE or upgrade to a fixed SBP Reorg failures here are usually space or Oracle bug related, not BRTOOLS itself.

entry.title: Re: Migration Monitor exits with error code 103
entry.content: This error is typical for very large SOFFCONT1 tables during export. R3load is limited to 256 data files per package. SAP Note 1922094 explains this clearly. Splitting the table into smaller packages or using the latest kernel/R3load version is the correct approach.

entry.title: Re: Content server - using RSIRPIRL - how to find PHIO cl...
entry.content:
In short: RSIRPIRL works at PHIO class level, not document type level.

  • SOFFCONT1 documents ‚Üí PHIO class SOFFPHIO, source category SOFFDB

  • BDS_CONT1 documents ‚Üí PHIO classes starting with BDS_* (e.g. BDS_DOC, BDS_IMAGE depending on usage)

Key concepts:

  • Repository (OAC0): Physical storage (Content Server)

  • Category (OACT): Logical routing to a repository

  • PHIO Class: Technical document handler (used by RSIRPIRL)

  • Document Type (OAC3): Only relevant for ArchiveLink, not for RSIRPIRL

SKPR08 is relevant only when you want new documents of a PHIO class to be stored in a specific category going forward.
It is not mandatory for RSIRPIRL migration itself.

RSIRPIRL cannot split documents by business document type (e.g. invoice vs PO).
Migration happens per PHIO class only.

For sizing, SOFFCONT1 and BDS_CONT1 table sizes (DB02 / HANA Studio) are the only reliable indicators before migration.

entry.title: Re: Content Repository Migration in mind ?
entry.content: Thanks for sharing this detailed overview of Content Repository Migration approaches. This post clearly explains when to use RSIRPIRL, Z_DOC_COPY, and Z_MIGRATE_ARCHIVELINK based on the application context (GOS, DMS, ArchiveLink, KPro). Very helpful for avoiding common mistakes like using a generic report for application‚Äëspecific attachments. This will definitely help during planning and sizing for large‚Äëscale migrations.

entry.title: Bulk upsert in SAP HANA
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I'm using mulesoft to perform bulk upsert in SAP HANA from a source table that has duplicate values, usually I expect to get a return of an array [1,1,1,1,...] but Im getting  [1,1,2,2,3,3,1,1,...]. Does anyone knows what 2 and 3 means?

entry.title: Re: Equipment :- Program logic to fetch Internal note and attachment from Equipment
entry.content: Thanks for the clarification. This helps a lot in understanding the difference between Equipment internal notes (stored in STXH/STXL via READ_TEXT) and attachments added via GOS/Services for Object (linked through SRGBTBREL and SAP Office tables like SOFFCONT1). This gives a clear direction for handling both in the workflow logic.

entry.title: Re: U.S Tax Reporter Year End 2025

Hello @joe_jones2 ,

If you don't generate W-2 PR on your system, you don't need to apply the Phase II Note for now.
This will be required if the note is set as a pre-requisite for another note, or the delivery will be on your system once you apply the corresponding support package.

Carlos

entry.title: Re: Document display from fb03 not possible
entry.content: This issue occurs because SOFFCONT1 was excluded during client copy, so the attachment content is missing. SOFFPHIO/SOFFOIO may exist, but without SOFFCONT1 the documents cannot be displayed. Transport is not recommended for a 50‚ÄØGB table‚Äîplease restore SOFFCONT1 from backup or re-copy it using a system copy / export‚Äìimport method.

entry.title: Re: User exit for adding text in PO History
entry.content: MO

entry.title: Re: U.S Tax Reporter Year End 2025
entry.content:
Hello @juli_thompson and @ConeC ,

SAP is closely monitoring with the Authority the reporting of Washington Cares in W-2 Box 14.
Do you have the Authority publication saying that this is required? So, I can share with SAP Product Management team for validation.

Thank you,
Carlos

entry.title: Re: how to retrieve data from content repository
entry.content:
When documents are relocated from SOFFCONT1 to an external Content Repository using RSIRPIRL, they are no longer accessed via ArchiveLink transactions (OAAD / OAOR).

These documents are SAPoffice / KPro documents, so they must be accessed through the original business object or SAPoffice, not directly from the repository.

Key points:

  • RSIRPIRL moves content physically and updates KPro metadata.

  • After relocation, SOFFCONT1 is empty, but metadata remains in:

    • SOFFPHIO

    • SOFFLOIO

    • SOC3 / SOOD

  • Verify that the storage category in SOFFPHIO has changed from SOFFDB to your target category.

  • End users can retrieve the documents only via the original transaction/object (e.g. GOS, attachment list), not via OAAD/OAOR.

  • OAAD/OAOR are relevant for ArchiveLink, not SAPoffice/KPro documents.

So, if the application linkage is intact, document access will continue transparently after relocation.

entry.title: Re: How to interpret SAP HANA DB table sizes definitions?
entry.content:
Explanation of DB02 table size metrics:

  • Estimated maximum memory consumption: Expected RAM usage when the table is fully loaded into memory (compressed, column-store).

  • Current memory consumption ‚Äì Main storage: Memory used by the main (merged, read-optimized) column store.

  • Current memory consumption ‚Äì Delta storage: Memory used by unmerged delta records (new/changed data).

  • Current total memory consumption: Main + Delta memory usage.

  • Size on disk: Physical persistence on disk (usually larger due to LOBs, history, and storage format).

Large differences (e.g., SOFFCONT1) are normal because LOB data is usually not fully loaded into memory.

entry.title: Re: Retreival of the Archived BCS (Buiness Communication...
entry.content:
There is no SAP‚Äëstandard or SAP‚Äësupported procedure to restore archived BCS (SOFFCONT1) data from the SAP Content Server back into the SAP database.

Reports like RSIRPIRL are designed as a one‚Äëway relocation from database to content repository to reduce DB growth. SAP does not provide any reverse report to reload content into SOFFCONT1.

Access to archived BCS data is expected to remain via the Content Server / SAPoffice framework, not by reinserting records into SOFFCONT1. Any attempt to bring data back would require custom development and is not recommended or supported by SAP, especially in S/4HANA due to HANA cost and data consistency risks.

entry.title: Re: U.S Tax Reporter Year End 2025
entry.content:
Hello @ChandraV,

The main delivery of note 3695859 (TAX: Technology and Customer Service Fee tax for Ohio) was to add the concept of UI Continuity for Ohio Tax Type 78, as per the Authority guideline.
In case your business is subject to Ohio Unemployment Surcharge Tax, Tax Type 78 needs to be added on your Tax Model.

Best Regards,
Carlos

entry.title: Re: Table to fetch the Title & the Address of the URL
entry.content:
For GOS ‚ÄúCreate external document (URL)‚Äù, the Title is stored in SOOD.
The URL/address itself is stored in table SOC3 (field depending on SAP release), not in SOFFCONT1.
URLs and notes are handled as SAPoffice documents; only PC attachments may go to SOFFCONT1/KPro.
Refer to SAP Note 530792 for the exact storage behavior.

entry.title: Re: SOC3 and SOFFCOUNT1 Archiving
entry.content:
SOC3 data can be archived using standard SAP tools such as report RSSOAPUT (BCS archiving).
However, SOFFCONT1 does not support archiving via SAP Archive Development Kit. Entries can only be deleted/reorganized (for example using RSBCS_REORG or by relocating content to a content server via RSIRPIRL).
Always test thoroughly before executing in production.

entry.title: Re: Find were the actual attachment is stored in table.
entry.content:
SOC3 data can be archived using report RSSOAPUT (after proper testing).
SOFFCONT1 cannot be archived via SAP archiving objects; it can only be deleted/reorganized using RSBCS_REORG or relocated to a content server using RSIRPIRL.
SAP does not provide a standard archive object for SOFFCONT1.

entry.title: Re: Moivng contents of SOC3 table to Content server
entry.content:
SOC3 data cannot be migrated to a Content Server in the same way as SOFFCONT1.

SOFFCONT1 stores large binary content managed via KPro and can be relocated to a Content Server using RSIRPIRL.

SOC3 mainly contains small contents such as notes, URLs, and metadata, and is not designed for KPro-based content server relocation. SAP does not provide any standard tool or procedure to move SOC3 content to a Content Server.

The supported approach for SOC3 is SAP Office archiving/deletion, for example using report RSSOAPUT, after proper testing.

If SOC3 is growing significantly, review usage patterns and housekeeping rather than content server migration.

entry.title: Re: Regarding the SAP big tables in ECC 6.0
entry.content:
These are standard SAP tables that typically grow over time.
‚Ä¢ TST03 ‚Äì Spool data; clean up using RSPO0041 / RSPO1041 and reorganize if oversized.
‚Ä¢ COEP ‚Äì CO line items; reduce size via CO archiving objects in SARA.
‚Ä¢ SOFFCONT1 ‚Äì SAP Office document content; reduce via reorganization/relocation (e.g. RSIRPIRL) and deletion policies.
‚Ä¢ GLPCA ‚Äì PCA line items; archive using EC-PCA archiving objects.
‚Ä¢ EDI40 ‚Äì IDoc data; delete/archive old IDocs (WE11 / SAP Note 40088).
Refer to the SAP Database Management Guide and relevant SAP Notes for prevention and cleanup.

entry.title: Re: After import table content is missing
entry.content: This is the correct approach for recovering SOFFCONT1 after an incomplete Unicode migration. Using R3load -merge_bck preserves newly created data and avoids overwriting active records. Important to validate dependencies and test carefully before production use.

entry.title: Re: Most allocated extents in any segment oracle 11g
entry.content:
For Oracle 11g with locally managed tablespaces, a high number of extents (even for LOB segments like SOFFCONT1) is not an issue because MAX_EXTENTS is UNLIMITED and extent sizes are managed automatically.
This CCMS alert is informational only. No action is required unless you see real space or performance problems.
Refer SAP Note 483856 for details.

entry.title: Re: How the project attachment file link to project?
entry.content:
In CJ20N, project attachments are linked via Generic Object Services (GOS) / BDS.
The relationship between the project (object type BUS2054 / PROJ) and attachments is stored in SRGBTBREL.
For SAPoffice attachments, document data is held in SOOD / SOFM / SOC3 / SOFFCONT1.

To retrieve attachments programmatically, use BDS_ALL_CONNECTIONS_GET (for BDS/ArchiveLink) or GOS APIs.
SAP Note 530792 explains the storage and linkage in detail.

entry.title: Re: Unknown objects in ABAP Dictionary
entry.content:
The unknown object SOFFCONT1#$ is a leftover from an interrupted BRSPACE table reorganization. It can be safely removed using:
brspace -f tbreorg -t SOFFCONT1#$ -a cleanup.

The SAP_AUXSTATS DB view belongs to DBA Cockpit/Oracle statistics and may appear as ‚Äúunknown‚Äù in older Basis releases. No manual action is recommended‚Äîopen an SAP incident if the warning persists.

entry.title: Re: Content Server Table for REBDPR Tcode
entry.content: Attachments in REBDPR are handled via SAPoffice. SOFFLOIO / SOFFPHIO store the logical & physical document references, while the actual content is stored in SOFFCONT1 (or an external content server if configured). See SAP Note 904711 for full details. SQL/ABAP trace during upload can confirm the flow.

entry.title: Re: Reduce size LOBSEGMENT
entry.content: Deleting entries from SOFFCONT1 does not automatically shrink the associated LOB segment. For LOBs, space is not released unless the LOB is moved or rebuilt. You need to reorganize the LOB segment explicitly (e.g. BRSPACE LOB reorg or MOVE LOB), or relocate content to a content server (RSIRPIRL). Otherwise, the LOB size remaining large is expected behavior.

entry.title: Re: what is the procedure to transfer attached documents...
entry.content:
There is no supported way to transfer attachments by transporting SOFFCONT1. Attachments are part of SAPoffice/KPro and must be moved using standard relocation tools.

If attachments are stored in the database, use RSIRPIRL to relocate them to a Content Server. If they are already on a Content Server, configure the new repository (OAC0/OACT/SKPR08) and perform a content server migration using SAP‚Äësupported tools (repository copy or vendor tools like OpenText).

Transporting SOFFCONT1 is not recommended and can lead to inconsistencies.

entry.title: Re: Content Repository Migration in mind ? Part IV Error in Migration
entry.content: Thanks for the detailed explanation. For Content Repository migration errors, checking SLG1 logs (objects SDOK and SCMS) is crucial to identify whether the issue is at the source or target repository. Verifying the target repository with RSCMST / RSCMSTH0 before reruns also helps avoid partial or inconsistent migrations. This blog is very helpful for troubleshooting RSIRPIRL-related issues.

entry.title: Re: systemVars.dimensions.viewport.height malfunction
entry.content: Apparently, this issue appears on some devices e.g. on Android 16, while older devices, e.g. Android 11 work properly!

entry.title: Re: Archiving Emails in CRM
entry.content: Email archiving in CRM is not done via WORKITEM archiving alone. Attachments are stored in SOFFCONT1 and should be relocated using RSIRPIRL to a content server. Email body/text stored in SOC3 / SAPoffice can be archived via SOY8. WORKITEM archiving is only relevant if emails are processed via SAP Connect workflow. SAP Note 904711 gives a good overview.

entry.title: Re: Dynamic table name in Select * From (Table_name)
entry.content:
you can select the data but that won't help you at all,
because there is no dynamic data target.

entry.title: Re: Row Compression in db2 9.7
entry.content: TST03 growth is mainly driven by LOB data, so DB2 row compression has limited effect. Best approach is housekeeping as per SAP Note 48400 or increasing INLINE LENGTH for the LOB. For SOFFCONT1, moving content to an external repository is recommended.

entry.title: TMS External Planning via CPI
entry.content:
There are many situations where a TMS application must connect with external or 3rd‚Äëparty systems such as JDE, MercuryGate, or legacy home‚Äëgrown applications. These integrations are typically implemented to exchange transportation data, automate business transactions, and maintain end-to-end visibility across the supply chain.

 

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/e3dc5400c1cc41d1bc0ae0e7fd9aa5a2/5505d7ffe42c496788d504e54ce80e59.html?locale=en-US

In a typical SAP TM landscape, standard SAP integration enables the system to send Freight Units (FUs) to an external or 3rd‚Äëparty Transportation Management application (such as JDE, MercuryGate, or a legacy system) without requiring any custom development.

The standard process works as follows:

  1. SAP TM creates Freight Units (FUs) based on sales orders, purchase orders, or deliveries.
  2. These FUs are sent to the 3rd‚Äëparty TMS using SAP‚Äôs out‚Äëof‚Äëthe‚Äëbox integration capabilities ( CPI,).
  3. The external TMS performs:
    • Load planning
    • Carrier selection
    • Routing
    • Tendering
  4. The 3rd‚Äëparty system then sends routing and carrier assignment confirmation back to SAP TM using the standard interface.
  5. SAP TM automatically:
    • Creates a Freight Order (FO) based on the received planning data
    • Links the FO to the original Freight Unit
    • Consumes the FU (i.e., the FU becomes assigned to the FO)

All of this is supported by SAP‚Äôs standard integration content, which means no custom development is required for core message flows or planning confirmation processing.

Configuration Steps : 

1. Enable the PPF action : TOR_TPNOR_FU at FU level using 

2. Activate the services in SICF 

3. Check the SRT_ADMIN report for Webservice and Task Watcher readiness (SAP support team help need to run the SRT_ADMIN in 000 client via serivce ticket)

4. Create SOAP endpoint in CPI

5. Expose/obtain the WSDL for that endpoint (from CPI).

6. Create Logical Port in SOAMANAGER for your DEV  unit test client

 How to Test : 

Here‚Äôs a clean, step‚Äëby‚Äëstep way to Generate a Freight Unit (FU) in SAP TM and verify that the PPF action triggers successfully and XML is generated for outbound integration ‚Äî exactly what you'd check during FU ‚Üí 3rd‚Äëparty integration testing.

For any errors , please check the tcode SRT_UTIL 

Summary : 

1. S/4 to External Planning system : TransportationOrderGenericRequest_Out

2. External Planning System to S/4 : TransportationOrderGenericRequest_In

If you want to receive charges from the external planning system, you must use the additional web service TransportationOrderChargeElementRequest_In, as charge transfers are not covered by the standard inbound service TransportationOrderGenericRequest_In.

 
Would like to share my findings with SAP community!

Thank you
Hari Sivvala

entry.title: Re: where is the attached file stored in ECC6.0?
entry.content:
In ECC 6.0, attachments (texts, screenshots, files) are typically stored in table SOFFCONT1 (content), with metadata in SOOD / SOFM.
There is no fixed SAP limit, but large attachments increase database size, so SAP recommends moving them to a Content Server

entry.title: Re: We have setup bank account to All currencies. And wan...
entry.content: If you mean house bank accounts, the currency is not defined by the bank account itself, but rather by GL account that is set for this bank. So if you want to change to a single currency, create new GL account with that currency and set this GL account on your bank account.

entry.title: Re: Using Custom Table API via Web Service (SOAP) after 2...
entry.content: Yes SOAP service will still be supported and it is not affected with announced changes.

entry.title: Re: Statement Level Trigger (SQL Anywhere 17)
entry.content:
To get the clean output, I chained a GREP command to the output of the dbmanageetd  basedon  SYS_Audit_String search pattern. This could also be handled with a regular expression if you do not have a grep tool on the system.

My last suggested delete trigger has a counter in the fetch loop that is used to detect and report a no-op delete statement.  If the counter is 0 after processing the NEW temp table, it means that the delete statement was a no-op.  In that case,, an audit string  "No row impacted by DELETE"  is logged. Note that this will only work with statement level triggers. and  It is really a rough idea of how this could be implemented.

entry.title: Re: what are the SAP inbox tables.
entry.content:
SAP Inbox (SBWP) data is mainly retrieved from workflow and SAPoffice tables.
Key tables include:

  • SWWUSERWI ‚Äì workflow work items for a specific user (main inbox driver)

  • SWWWIHEAD / SWWWIAGENT ‚Äì work item header and agent assignment

  • SOC3 ‚Äì SAPoffice document content (mail/body)

  • SOOD / SOOS ‚Äì SAPoffice document headers and status

  • SOFFCONT1 ‚Äì attachments

A large inbox (e.g. 37k entries) usually causes timeout due to SWWUSERWI volume.
Using workflow archiving and inbox cleanup is recommended.

entry.title: Re: Reorganize/Archive SAPOffice documents
entry.content:
Your understanding is largely correct.

  • RSBCS_REORG deletes SAPoffice documents (cleanup, not real archiving).

  • Mass archiving of historical SAPoffice documents (e.g. year-based) is not supported by SAP standard.

  • Documents can be stored in a content repository via storage category configuration, but this applies mainly to newly created documents.

  • For existing documents, realistic options are deletion via RSBCS_REORG / SOY5 / SOY8 or using third‚Äëparty tools to move content from SOFFCONT1 to an external repository.

entry.title: Re: TDMS functionality question - Time slice scenario
entry.content:
In TDMS time-based slice scenarios, SAP Office tables (including SOFFCONT1) are not transferred. Attachments stored in SOFFCONT1 are excluded, while DMS tables like DMS_CONT1_CD1 are transferred in full.

By default, TDMS excludes SAP Office, Workflow, Change Docs, Users/Roles, Variants, and similar technical data.
Time-based scenarios transfer full master data + reduced transactional data.
Runtime depends heavily on hardware, parallel jobs, and table sizes‚Äîthere‚Äôs no reliable generic estimate.

entry.title: how to setup resource group in the Joule Agent Builder
entry.content:
Hi,

I am trying create a Joule Agent using Joule Agent Builder in SAP Build Joule Studio. I am trying to add a tool of type document in the agent.

 

When I try to add document, its asking to add resource group in the control tower.  I am not able to understand what should be added as AI core Destination and Object Store destination. Do we have to setup destination which points SAP AI core service and SAP Object Store service instances. entry.title: Re: Table still fragmented after REORG !!
entry.content: Conclusion: PCL2 is not actually fragmented. The high ‚Äúwasted space‚Äù reported by the script from SAP Note 821687 is misleading because the table contains a LOB (BLOB) column. When analyzed with DBMS_SPACE (Note 1295200 / 1438410), fragmentation is minimal and UNUSED_MB is low. REORG was therefore not required

entry.title: Re: Prevent tables from loading into memory
entry.content: You cannot prevent tables from loading into HANA memory. Unload priority only affects when they are unloaded. Best practice is to archive/reorganize workflow and PI tables, and move SOFFCONT1 attachments to an external content repository (per SAP Note 1634908). Dynamic tiering can also be considered for warm data.

entry.title: Re: Database error <>
entry.content:
We faced the same Database error <GET DATA FROM KPRO> issue after upgrade.
Root cause was missing SOFFCONT1 content for old PHIOs due to incomplete data during system copy/upgrade.
Restoring affected documents from backup resolved the issue.
New documents were unaffected.

entry.title: Re: Where SAP store the uploaded files?
entry.content:
Uploaded files are not stored automatically by SAP.
In Web Dynpro, the FileUpload UI element only holds the file temporarily in memory (XSTRING).
The application decides where to store it:

  • SAP Office / KPro ‚Üí SOFFCONT1 (or Content Server if configured)

  • DMS / GOS / ArchiveLink ‚Üí external content repository

  • Custom logic ‚Üí database table or application server (AL11)

Physical storage is explained in SAP Note 904711.

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Silent Data Migration Infrastructure (Quick Guide)
entry.content: Thanks for the clear overview of SDMI and the real upgrade experience. For anyone looking to go deeper, SAP Note 2842212 and the SDMI quick guide on SAP Training provide helpful technical and functional details around setup, monitoring, and prerequisites.

entry.title: Re: Is Selective Data Transition the Best Fit for Your SA...
entry.content:
There is no single ‚Äúbest‚Äù migration approach for all customers.
The right choice between Brownfield, Greenfield, or Selective Data Transition (SDT) depends on business goals, system complexity, data volume, and transformation scope.

  • Brownfield fits customers who want a faster technical conversion with minimal process change.

  • Greenfield is ideal when major process redesign and clean-core adoption are priorities.

  • Selective Data Transition works well when customers need to retain specific historical data and critical processes while still modernizing selectively.

A detailed assessment of data, custom code, timelines, and business readiness is essential before deciding the migration path.

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Conversion - t5 - Custom Code Migration step-by-step
entry.content: Thanks for sharing this detailed overview. The comparison between Greenfield, Brownfield, and Selective Data Transition clearly highlights how to choose the right approach based on scope, data, and transformation needs. Very helpful for planning an S/4HANA migration.

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA System Conversion
entry.content: Thanks for sharing this detailed overview of S/4HANA system conversion. It gives a clear end‚Äëto‚Äëend picture of technical, functional, and data migration activities. Even though it‚Äôs an older post, many fundamentals are still very useful for understanding the conversion approach.

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA On-premise vs Cloud
